oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The legal Research Department of the Wman's Party has not entirely completed its survey of the Tennessee laws relating to women. Only major subjects have been covered. The following is a list of some of Tennessee's discriminations against women: 1 (stricken through) The father alone is the natural guardian of his children. Ross v. Cobbm 9 Yer. 463: Miles v. Kaigler, 10 Yer. 10. The mother is not a natural guardian of her own child unless the father is dead or a deserter. 2. When a married woman dies without a will, her husband gets her entire personal estate. On the other hand, when a married man dies without a will, his wife gets only a child's share in his personal estate. Only if there are no children does she get his entire personal estate. 3. The husbandis entitled to use for his life all the real estate of his deceased wife, provided a child was born alive during the marriage. The wife, on the other hand, is entitled to use for her life of only one-third of her deceased husband's lands. 4. Women are excluded from jury service. 5. The father inherits all the personal estate of a child who dies without a will and without descendants. The mother inherits the personal estate of her deceased child only if the father is dead, and even then she must share the inheritance with the brothers and sisters of the decedent. 6. A mother is not entitled to sue for damages for an injury to her minor child unless the father is dead or has deserted. The right to sue belongs exclusively to the father except in the in- stances named. 7. A husband is entitled to his wife's services and he may recover for the loss of such services by reason of personal in- juries sustained by her. In such a case the wife collects damages only for her pain and suffering. When a married man is injured, he recovers all damages.
